abstract: Belgian prosecutors announce capture of Mohamed Abrini, saying he has confessed to helping  suicide bombers who executed deadly attack at Brussels Airport in March; Abrini, who had been seen in airport security footage wearing hat and walking away from bombing, appears also to be linked to 2015 terror attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Abrini, who was detained Friday, confessed he was the suspect seen with two suicide bombers in a surveillance image, the Belgian prosecutor’s office said.
snippet: Mohamed Abrini, who was detained Friday, confessed he was the suspect seen with two suicide bombers in a surveillance image, the Belgian prosecutor’s office said....

headline.print_headline: Brussels Airport Suspect Is in Custody
headline.main: Man in Hat in Brussels Airport Attack Is in Custody, Belgium Says

abstract: Counterterrorism officials say there is evidence that Islamic State was building machinery to mount sustained terrorist strikes in Europe long before attacks in Brussels and Paris, but authorities missed connections; since March 2014, ISIS has carried out or inspired at least 29 deadly assaults targeting Westerners around world, killing more than 650 people (Series: State of Terror).
lead_paragraph: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts....

headline.print_headline: Long Before Brussels, ISIS Sent Terror Operatives to Europe
headline.main: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt from Washington, Laure Fourquet and Aurelien Breeden from Paris, Katrin Bennhold from London, Andrew Higgins from Brussels, and Runa Sandvik from New York. Alain Delaquérière and Karen Yourish contributed research.

abstract: Europe's porous borders and outdated security apparatus have aided Islamic State in launching terrorist attacks across European capitals like Brussels; group has also been helped by growing network of operatives spread throughout continent that are increasingly indiscriminate about killing.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State has chosen the capitals of Western Europe to score military victories, and has been aided by a combination of porous borders and a calcified security apparatus.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: The Islamic State has chosen the capitals of Western Europe to score military victories, and has been aided by a combination of porous borders and a calcified security apparatus....

headline.print_headline: Porous Borders and Calcified Security Aid Islamic State in Europe
headline.main: Porous Borders and Calcified Security Aid Islamic State in Europe

byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt and Scott Shane contributed reporting.

abstract: Bombings in Brussels, where officials have been on high alert for terrorism, deepen uncertainty over efficacy of Europe's antiterrorism intelligence; increased persistence and proliferation of terrorist cells adds to worries; attacks have spawned deep questions over whether Europe should redouble efforts at expense of civil liberties or whether terrorism is inevitable.
lead_paragraph: In an age of easy travel and rising militancy, intelligence experts fear that terrorist attacks have become an unavoidable part of life in Europe.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: In an age of easy travel and rising militancy, intelligence experts fear that terrorist attacks have become an unavoidable part of life in Europe....

headline.main: Brussels Attacks Underscore Vulnerability of an Open European Society

abstract: Security at Super Bowl 50 will be tighter than at previous events, as authorities work with heightened urgency following Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: Security, always a concern at the Super Bowl, has received greater focus this year after the attacks in Paris in November, when terrorists struck several venues, including Stade de France.
snippet: Security, always a concern at the Super Bowl, has received greater focus this year after the attacks in Paris in November, when terrorists struck several venues, including Stade de France....

headline.main: Officials Offer Reassurances on Security at Super Bowl

abstract: Battle to retake city of Mosul, Iraq, from Islamic State has settled into grinding war of attrition, with high numbers of security force and civilian casualties and immobile front line; up to one million people are trapped inside city, with food and water supplies running low; situation is likely to be among main national security issues facing Pres-elect Donald Trump when he takes office.
lead_paragraph: Up to a million people are trapped inside Iraq’s second-largest city, where the brutal urban war of attrition is proving to be tougher than expected.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: Up to a million people are trapped inside Iraq’s second-largest city, where the brutal urban war of attrition is proving to be tougher than expected....

headline.print_headline: Carnage, Hunger  and Fear in Iraq
headline.main: Hungry, Thirsty and Bloodied in Battle to Retake Mosul From ISIS

byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Istanbul; Eric Schmitt from Doha, Qatar; and Rukmini Callimachi from Erbil, Iraq. Falih Hassan contributed reporting from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Erbil.

abstract: Actual identity and motives of Germany's first suicide bomber, known by authorities as Mohammad Daleel and by Islamic State as Abu Yousef, remains unknown almost two weeks after he detonated explosive at music festival; lack of clear information is raising concerns about refugee policies of Chancellor Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: Mohammad Daleel, 27, wounded 15 people last month, three years after entering Europe illegally through Bulgaria. He received mental health therapy, and his full identity and motives remain unclear.
